awd_titl_txt: New Tools in the Study of Wave Propagation: Dynamical Systems for Kinetic Equations, Inviscid Limits for Modulated Periodic Waves, and Rigorous Numerical Stability Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will study a selection of key open problems in the theory of wave propagation arising in a variety of settings including thin film flow, pattern formation, detonation, and the kinetic theory of gases.  The problems considered share the features of computational complexity, multiple length/time scales, and genuine physical interest in applications.  Many concern questions that current numerics and experiment are not adequate to resolve.  Several of the planned subprojects involve numerically assisted proof using scientific computation with guaranteed error bounds, up to and including rigorous numerical proof.  An integral part of the project is the simultaneous development of a user-friendly numerical platform, STABLAB, for numerical stability investigation, and the systematic exploration with this platform of physical behavior in gas and fluid dynamics in the delicate situations of reacting or ionized flow.  

The problems addressed involve issues in dynamical systems, singular perturbation theory, spectral theory of linear operators, nonlinear partial differential equations, and rigorous scientific computation, and should result in the development of new mathematical tools of general application. In particular, development of dynamical systems tools for kinetic shock and boundary layer problems would unify and extend results obtained for Boltzmann phenomena by the "Kyoto School" of Sone et al using a variety of formal and analytic methods. Likewise, the introduction of new inviscid stability criteria for roll waves and of Kreiss symmetrizer techniques for analysis of modulated fronts open new directions in the study of periodic modulation. The problem on galloping detonations, if solved, will answer a longstanding question, while associated rigorous Wensel,Kramers, and Brillouin method developments will be of wide general use. Determination of simple stability criteria for roll waves in shallow water flow are of practical interest in hydraulic engineering. Finally, the development of rigorous numerical proof and error estimate techniques is potentially transformative, having broader implications for standards in scientific computing.

por.por_cntn:
In this grant period, we have made substantial advances in kinetic theory (Boltzmann's equation), stability of hydraulic shock and periodic roll wave solutions in inclined shallow water flow (Saint Venant equations),and multidimensional modulation of large-amplitude periodic solutions of reaction diffusion systems (e.g.,Belousov Zhabotinsky/Brusselator equations), in addition opening new areas of study in convective Turing bifurcations arising in biomorphological pattern formation (e.g., vasculogenesis), and  existence/uniqueness for the ``shock tube problem'' (compressible Navier-Stokes equations in a finite length duct).

Specifically: 1. We developed dynamical system tools for the infinite dimensional  Boltzmann equation generalizing stable and center manifold theorems for finite dimensional differential equations, greatly simplifying the existence theory for small amplitude Boltzmann shock and boundary layers and making some first baby steps toward treatment of large amplitude shocks, a major open problem in the area.  Small amplitude Boltzmann, or particle-model shocks (by center manifold construction) are arbitrarily well approximated by standard continuum-model shocks found in the compressible Navier-Stokes equations.  However, for large amplitudes, Boltzmann shocks are seen to predict experimental observation much more closely than Navier-Stokes shocks, motivating their further study.

2. We developed rigorous and practically useful new theory for stability of roll waves, obtaining a complete stability diagram in all parameters. Remarkably, the main, low-frequency stability boundary is found explicitly, as the solution of a cubic equation convenient for engineering application. Roll waves are a type of ``mini-rogue wave'' developing from instabilities in fast-flowing, or sharply inclined flow in an open channel.  It is important for hydraulic engineering applications (e.g. canals) under what circumstances these waves can exist as stable objects, since their height is much greater than that for a designed laminar flow; yet, previous studies in the high-speed regime relevant to engineering, based on formal ``back-of-the-envelope'' computations, were both confusing and sometimes contradictory.

3. We proved completely analytically the linearized and nonlinear time-asymptotic stability of hydraulic shock solutions in open channel flow, across all parameters.  Such an explicit linearized result is, again, rare and remarkable.  But also the nonlinear result is one of a very few long-time stability results for waves containitng discontinuities, hence a theoretical breakthrough for general systems of equations of ``quasilinear hyperbolic relaxation'' type.

4. We established for the first time validity of ``modulation approximations'' of large amplitude multi-dimensional patterns in reaction diffusion systems using a novel transfer of technology from hyperbolic shock and boundary layer theory in form the of ``Kreiss symmetrizer'' estimates and pseudodifferential techniques. Previous results proved by completely different techniques were limited to one dimension (in particular not including 2d `target''-type solutions motivating the original development of modulation approximations) and small amplitudes.

5. With grad student Aric Wheeler, we extended the famous Turing  and weakly nonlinear Ginzburg Landau theoris of pattern formation and stability in reaction diffusion models to models arising in modern biomorphology including also mechanical (``convective'') forces and conservation laws (conserved quantities), making possible for the first time the systematic study of resulting patterns from small-amplitude initiation.  In particular this involves coupling of complex Ginzburg Landau equation with a *singular* convection equation featuring speeds blowing up as one over amplitude squared. Pattern formation and emergence of dynamical behavior are two frontline areas of investigation in math biology these days.  Our hope is that item 5 describing initiation/formation togehter a generalization of item 4 describing modulation/emergent behavior can be of help in systemetizing these investigations.

6. We identified an interesting set of unsolved problems in the study of the ``shock tube'' problem, or compressible gas-dynamics equations on a finite channel wiith prescribed inflow--outflow conditions at the end, and proved some first, one-dimensional results in this direction.  Ultimately, this should leasd to multi-d and interesting problems in shock/viscous boundary-layer interactions, such as are important in hypersonic flight; however, such developments appear far in the future.
